title: 112_hr3580
content: Section 301(a) of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to include subtotals for different types of spending. Additionally, a new subsection is added for long-term budgeting, requiring levels to be set as a percent of the current GDP for various financial aspects. The Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to include subtotals for different types of spending and a new subsection for long-term budgeting, requiring levels to be set as a percent of the current GDP for various financial aspects. Additionally, it mandates reporting on Federal revenues, outlays, debt held by the public, and the budget surplus or deficit for the fiscal year 10, 20, and 30 years after the last fiscal year of the budget resolution. SEC. 9. LONG-TERM RECONCILIATION. Long-Term Reconciliation: A concurrent resolution on the budget may include long-term reconciliation directives to reduce spending levels for Medicare, Medicaid, OASDI Trust Funds, and other direct spending outlays as a percentage of gross domestic product. The committee is tasked with recommending reductions in spending as a percentage of GDP. Amendments to reconciliation legislation cannot decrease outlay reductions below specified levels. The Senate cannot consider amendments to a reconciliation bill that reduce spending below specified levels unless a declaration of war is in effect. Outlays as a percentage of GDP for a fiscal year are determined by the Committee on the Budget. In the Senate, a motion to strike a provision is always allowed. In the Senate, a motion to strike a provision is always in order for long-term reconciliation bills, which can include parts of the Medicare Program, Medicaid, the Old-Age, Survivors, and Disability Insurance Trust Fund, and other direct spending. Certain sections do not apply to these measures, and necessary reforms for program restructuring are not considered extraneous. The Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to include subsection (h) in addition to subsection (a). SEC. 10. LONG-TERM SPENDING INCREASE POINT OF ORDER. Amends the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 to include a new section on long-term spending increase point of order. The Director of the Congressional Budget Office must estimate if a bill causes a net increase in direct spending exceeding $5 billion over four ten-year periods. The Senate cannot consider any legislation causing deficits over $5 billion in the same periods. The recently enacted concurrent resolution on the budget sets a limit on deficit increases in the House of Representatives to $5 billion over four ten-year periods. Estimates provided by the chairmen of the Senate and House Committees on the Budget determine the levels of net deficit increases. SEC. 11. CBO AND OMB PROJECTIONS. The Congressional Budget Office is required to issue long-term projections on spending, revenue, deficits, and debt for at least 40 years. This includes a Spending Review Report to be transmitted to the Committees on the Budget of the House of Representatives and the Senate. The Spending Review Report must include analyses on the solvency of OASDI, sustainability of Medicare spending levels, Medicaid and other health-related spending sustainability, sustainability of other direct spending levels, long-term sustainability of total Government outlays, deficit, and debt, as well as projections of net interest. The Spending Review Report must analyze the solvency of OASDI and sustainability of Medicare, Medicaid, and other health-related spending, as well as projections of net interest. The Office of Management and Budget is required to provide long-term projections of total spending over 30 years as a percentage of GDP annually, including the impact of proposed policies. SEC. 12. Long-term analysis by Congressional Budget Office of legislation. This section amends the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 to include long-term analysis by the Congressional Budget Office of legislation. Sec. 407 requires the Director of the Congressional Budget Office to prepare cost estimates for major legislation and bills requested by specific committees or members, covering a ten-year fiscal period. Sec. 407 mandates the Director of the Congressional Budget Office to provide cost estimates for major legislation with significant financial impact, defined as exceeding .25 percent of the GDP. The estimates must be submitted to the relevant committee before the accompanying report is filed. Sec. 407 amends the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 to require the Congressional Budget Office to provide long-term analysis for legislation in at least 9 fiscal years. Additionally, Sec. 13 and Sec. 14 amend sections related to long-term budgeting and financial condition reporting in the President's budget submissions. The Government Accountability Office must report on the financial condition of the Government, including long-term unfunded obligations, within 6 weeks of the President's budget submission. The definition of long-term unfunded obligations includes the Total Net Position and 75-year actuarial balances of Medicare's Hospital Insurance. The curr_chunk discusses the actuarial balances of various trust funds, including Medicare, Old-Age Survivors and Disability Insurance, Black Lung Disability Trust Fund, and Rail Industry Pension Fund. The curr_chunk discusses amending the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 to include a report on the financial condition of the Government's long-term unfunded obligations in the President's budget submission. The curr_chunk discusses a Medicare trigger. The curr_chunk amends Section 803 of the Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement, and Modernization Act of 2003 by adding new requirements related to reports and analyses. The curr_chunk adds new requirements for reports and analyses to Section 803 of the Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement, and Modernization Act of 2003, including a certification process and a fallback procedure for floor consideration if the House fails to vote on final passage by July 30. The curr_chunk amends Section 804 of the Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement, and Modernization Act of 2003 by adding new subsections regarding the inapplicability of procedures to certain legislation. It specifies that certain changes in budget authority and revenue increases are exempt from the procedures outlined in the section. The curr_chunk amends Section 805 of the Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement, and Modernization Act of 2003 by making changes to subsections (d)(1) and (e), including the discharge of medicare funding legislation from the committee and making the motion to proceed nondebatable. The curr_chunk introduces a new section 805 regarding the dedication of savings in budget legislation. It amends the Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement, and Modernization Act of 2003 by adjusting allocations to reflect budget impacts achieved by introduced legislation.
